title: How to Make a Hovercraft

steps.headline: Cut a circle from a piece of plywood.
steps.description:
Purchase a strong square of plywood and cut a circle ~36-48" in diameter. You will probably need to use a jigsaw to cut the circle from the plywood, but you can use another method if you are more comfortable with one. Sand the edges when you are done to avoid painful splinters. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/99\/Make-a-Hovercraft-Step-1Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Hovercraft-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/99\/Make-a-Hovercraft-Step-1Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Hovercraft-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":355,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":587.0344827586207,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Cut another circle.
steps.description: You will need a smaller circle of plywood, roughly 6”-1' in diameter. This will be used later.

steps.headline: Cut a hole from the main circle.
steps.description:
About halfway between the center and the edge, trace the end of a straw onto the larger circle. Cut out the traced circle using a Swiss Army Knife. Remove the straw when you are done checking for fit. Check for a good fit by putting your straw in the hole. If it doesn't fit well, you can seal it later using duct tape. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/0b\/Make-a-Hovercraft-Step-3Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Hovercraft-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/0b\/Make-a-Hovercraft-Step-3Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Hovercraft-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":355,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":587.0344827586207,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Cut out your plastic cushion.
steps.description: Cut the plastic sheeting in a circle, about 1' wider than the main circle. Wrap the excess plastic over the edge of the circle and staple it down using a staple gun, about every 4”. If you want, use duct tape to tape down the extra plastic and seal any gaps at the edge. The side covered in plastic is the underside of the hovercraft.

steps.headline: Strengthen the plastic.
steps.description: Turn the board over so that the plastic side is facing up. Take duct tape and use it to completely cover the roughly 1" sq area at the center of the circle. It should be at least a little larger than the small circle you cut out in step 2 of the previous section. For example, if you just use a 6” diameter circle, reinforce a 1” sq. area of plastic.

steps.headline: Attach the smaller circle to the larger one.
steps.description: Use wood screws to attach the smaller circle to the larger circle, at the exact center on the underside of the hovercraft. These screws should be no longer than the depth of both circles. Use roughly 5 screws to get a tight fit.

steps.headline: Cut holes in the plastic.
steps.description: At least 2" from the edge of the smaller circle but still in the reinforced area, cut 6 holes in the plastic. This will let the air escape, creating the cushion on which the hovercraft floats. These holes should be ~1” wide.

steps.headline: Insert an air blower.
steps.description: Flip the board right side up and place the end of the air blower in the appropriate hole.

steps.headline: Tape the air blower into place.
steps.description: Use duct tape to seal the hole tight and attach the blower firmly to the board.

steps.headline: Turn on the leaf-blower and enjoy riding around!
steps.description: You may have to lift the hovercraft up off the ground a bit at first, to help the initial airflow fill the cushion.

text:
Building the Board Cut a circle from a piece of plywood. Purchase a strong square of plywood and cut a circle ~36-48" in diameter. You will probably need to use a jigsaw to cut the circle from the plywood, but you can use another method if you are more comfortable with one. Sand the edges when you are done to avoid painful splinters. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/99/Make-a-Hovercraft-Step-1Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Hovercraft-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/99/Make-a-Hovercraft-Step-1Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Hovercraft-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":355,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":587.0344827586207,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Cut another circle. You will need a smaller circle of plywood, roughly 6”-1' in diameter. This will be used later. Cut a hole from the main circle. About halfway between the center and the edge, trace the end of a straw onto the larger circle. Cut out the traced circle using a Swiss Army Knife. Remove the straw when you are done checking for fit. Check for a good fit by putting your straw in the hole. If it doesn't fit well, you can seal it later using duct tape. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0b/Make-a-Hovercraft-Step-3Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Hovercraft-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0b/Make-a-Hovercraft-Step-3Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Hovercraft-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":355,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":587.0344827586207,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Building the Air Cushion Cut out your plastic cushion. Cut the plastic sheeting in a circle, about 1' wider than the main circle. Wrap the excess plastic over the edge of the circle and staple it down using a staple gun, about every 4”. If you want, use duct tape to tape down the extra plastic and seal any gaps at the edge. The side covered in plastic is the underside of the hovercraft. Strengthen the plastic. Turn the board over so that the plastic side is facing up. Take duct tape and use it to completely cover the roughly 1" sq area at the center of the circle. It should be at least a little larger than the small circle you cut out in step 2 of the previous section. For example, if you just use a 6” diameter circle, reinforce a 1” sq. area of plastic. Attach the smaller circle to the larger one. Use wood screws to attach the smaller circle to the larger circle, at the exact center on the underside of the hovercraft. These screws should be no longer than the depth of both circles. Use roughly 5 screws to get a tight fit. Cut holes in the plastic. At least 2" from the edge of the smaller circle but still in the reinforced area, cut 6 holes in the plastic. This will let the air escape, creating the cushion on which the hovercraft floats. These holes should be ~1” wide. Finishing Your Hovercraft Insert an air blower. Flip the board right side up and place the end of the air blower in the appropriate hole. Tape the air blower into place. Use duct tape to seal the hole tight and attach the blower firmly to the board. Turn on the leaf-blower and enjoy riding around! You may have to lift the hovercraft up off the ground a bit at first, to help the initial airflow fill the cushion.
sentences: Building the Board Cut a circle from a piece of plywood.
Purchase a strong square of plywood and cut a circle ~36-48" in diameter.
You will probably need to use a jigsaw to cut the circle from the plywood, but you can use another method if you are more comfortable with one.
Sand the edges when you are done to avoid painful splinters.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/99\/Make-a-Hovercraft-Step-1Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Hovercraft-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/99\/Make-a-Hovercraft-Step-1Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Hovercraft-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":355,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":587.0344827586207,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Cut another circle.
You will need a smaller circle of plywood, roughly 6”-1' in diameter.
This will be used later.
Cut a hole from the main circle.
About halfway between the center and the edge, trace the end of a straw onto the larger circle.
Cut out the traced circle using a Swiss Army Knife.
Remove the straw when you are done checking for fit.
Check for a good fit by putting your straw in the hole.
If it doesn't fit well, you can seal it later using duct tape.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/0b\/Make-a-Hovercraft-Step-3Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Hovercraft-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/0b\/Make-a-Hovercraft-Step-3Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Hovercraft-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":355,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":587.0344827586207,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Building the Air Cushion Cut out your plastic cushion.
Cut the plastic sheeting in a circle, about 1' wider than the main circle.
Wrap the excess plastic over the edge of the circle and staple it down using a staple gun, about every 4”.
If you want, use duct tape to tape down the extra plastic and seal any gaps at the edge.
The side covered in plastic is the underside of the hovercraft.
Strengthen the plastic.
Turn the board over so that the plastic side is facing up.
Take duct tape and use it to completely cover the roughly 1" sq area at the center of the circle.
It should be at least a little larger than the small circle you cut out in step 2 of the previous section.
For example, if you just use a 6” diameter circle, reinforce a 1” sq.
area of plastic.
Attach the smaller circle to the larger one.
Use wood screws to attach the smaller circle to the larger circle, at the exact center on the underside of the hovercraft.
These screws should be no longer than the depth of both circles.
Use roughly 5 screws to get a tight fit.
Cut holes in the plastic.
At least 2" from the edge of the smaller circle but still in the reinforced area, cut 6 holes in the plastic.
This will let the air escape, creating the cushion on which the hovercraft floats.
These holes should be ~1” wide.
Finishing Your Hovercraft Insert an air blower.
Flip the board right side up and place the end of the air blower in the appropriate hole.
Tape the air blower into place.
Use duct tape to seal the hole tight and attach the blower firmly to the board.
Turn on the leaf-blower and enjoy riding around!
You may have to lift the hovercraft up off the ground a bit at first, to help the initial airflow fill the cushion.
tyn_section: Thick plastic sheeting (like a shower curtain liner)
